description.narrative:
Stakeholder effects: Increased access to working capital and trade finance for BBI's customers (FIs and traders) in IDA PSW/FCS countries in Africa. This Project is expected to sustain BBI's ability to maintain liquidity and access to working capital to these customers in IDA/FCS countries. Given the short term nature of the trade transactions financed by BBI, IFC anticipates that BBI will maintain/provide access to finance to customers across IDA PSW countries for a total volume of up to US 300 million over the life of the Project.
Market Creation: Integration: By supporting BBI's liquidity needs and its ability to provide trade finance services despite COVID 19 IFC's facility is intended to promote the integration of trade finance markets in the Africa region. This will be achieved by maintaining and expanding trade finance corridors and trade linkages through bolstering correspondent banking network that serves as an enabling platform. This Project will help to protect the essential platform of myriad cross border trade finance linkages, which supports trade in these countries. In addition, it will contribute to the maintenance of financial stability by providing comfort to other market participants, beyond the Project, that are under pressure to retrench from African markets during this economic crisis. To measure the progress against this outcome, IFC will track the number of additional IDA PSW markets where the Bank is currently not actively supporting trade finance.

The proposed investment is a Working Capital Solutions (WCS) facility to BMCE Bank International Plc (BBI or the Bank) of up to US$50 million to be provided by IFC (the Project). The proposed loan will have a tenor of 2 years, renewable for one additional year at IFCs sole discretion, for a maximum aggregate tenor of up to 3 years. The Project will provide BBI with funding to support its trade lending activities to import and export of essential goods throughout IDA/FCS countries in Africa. BBIs trade finance portfolio is highly diversified. Currently, BBI has exposure to 18 IDA PSW countries in Africa, accounting for 55% of total exposure. This follow-on Project complements an up to US$75 million risk sharing facility under the Global Trade Liquidity Program. The Project is expected to be supported by the IDA Private Sector Window Blended Finance Facility (PSW BFF) as described in the Blended Finance Section.
